dt: {bc}to refuse to accept the existence, truth, or validity of

dt.t: You can't {wi}deny{/wi} that he's a good singer.

dt: {bc}to report or note the absence of (a symptom)

pt: {sc}deny{/sc} {sc}gainsay{/sc} {sc}contradict{/sc} {sc}contravene{/sc} mean to refuse to accept as true or valid. {sc}deny{/sc} implies a firm refusal to accept as true, to grant or concede, or to acknowledge the existence or claims of.
{sc}gainsay{/sc} implies disputing the truth of what another has said.
{sc}contradict{/sc} implies an open or flat denial.
{sc}contravene{/sc} implies not so much an intentional opposition as some inherent incompatibility.

et: Middle English {it}denien,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}denier, deneier{/it} (also continental Old French), from {it}de-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} (reinforcing the meaning of the base verb) + {it}nier{/it} "to renounce, deny, refuse" (after Latin {it}dēnegāre{/it} "to deny"), going back to Latin {it}negāre{/it} "to say (with the negative of a conjoined clause), deny, say no" {ma}{mat|negate|}{/ma}
